https://studio.code.org/s/csd5-2019/less.long_instructions:
# 5-Bit Number

When you only had four bits, the highest number that you could make was fifteen.  Now you'll have a chance to work with more bits to make higher numbers.

In this activity, the dots are replaced with numbers, but you still add up everything that's showing to see what number the binary code stands for.  The left-most bit doesn't have a number yet, so you'll have to give it one.

# Do This

-   Click on the bits to turn them on and off, and see the different numbers you can make.
-   With your partner, discuss the pattern in the numbers.  Decide what number you think should go in the left most box.
-   Click "Edit" to change the value of the left most bit.
-   Once you've decided on the value, try to make the following numbers: 16, 27, 31

https://studio.code.org/s/csd5-2019/less.long_instructions:
# Decoding multiple numbers

Here's a widget that can calculate numbers up to to eight bits. You can use it to find the values of the two world records below.

Don't forget to make sure that the "1" bit is always the right most bit.  If you have extra bits on the left side of the widget, just keep them turned off.

[][0]

1.  Longest tail on a dog (in inches) (5 bits)
2.  Most spoons balanced on someone's face (5 bits)

# Do This

-   Decode the two numbers from a the binary string.
    -   _Hint: You'll need to read the numbers in order, with the first answer using the first five bits, and the second answer using the five bits after that._

# Decoding multiple numbers

Here's a new bit string.  This time, you don't know the bit length of the two numbers.  Try to decode the numbers without knowing the bit length.

[][0]

1.  Largest wind chime, in feet (? bits)
2.  Furthest arrow shot with someone's feet (in feet) (? bits)

# Do This

-   Try to decode the two numbers from the binary string.
-   Discuss with your partner why you cannot know for sure whether your answer is correct.
https://studio.code.org/s/csd5-2019/less.teacher_markdown: Without knowing the length of each of the numbers, students will not be certain of their answers, but they should be able to at least find one possible solution.  Allow students to discuss any differences in their answers.  They should eventually see that they need to know the bit length of each number to answer the question.

https://studio.code.org/s/csd5-2019/less.long_instructions:
# Bit Length

If you don't know how many bits long each number is, you won't be able to decode a string of numbers.

For example, the following binary string could be decoded many different ways.

[][0]

If you split the string like this, the string reads 10, 84.

[][1] [][2]

If you split it like this, the string reads 42, 20.

[][3] [][4]

To solve this problem, people agree on a fixed length for every number.  The following string uses the same two numbers, but each number takes up exactly eight bits, no matter how many bits it actually needs.

[][5]

# Do This

-   Use the binary widget to decode the string that uses eight bit numbers.
-   Check you answer with a partner to see whether you got the same answer.

https://studio.code.org/s/csd5-2019/less.long_instructions:
## Questions to Consider

-   Why are all the types of data on the computer stored as numbers?
-   If everything is stored as a number, how do you think the computer tell the difference between numbers, letters, images, and sound?
https://studio.code.org/s/csd5-2019/less.teacher_markdown:
## Discussion Goals

Th goal of this discussion is to have the students think more deeply about the purpose of binary.  For the first question, they may want to return to their ASCII character sheets and see how the computer would interpret the same binary sequence as a number.  For their image representation, they may wonder whether it is even useful to interpret the binary sequences as numbers.  In the end, the purpose of defining all data as numbers is less about the "reality" of what the ones and zeros represent, and more about how binary is traditionally interpreted.

For the second question, allow students to think of different ways that the computer would distinguish between different types of data.  While it's not necessary for students to come up with any specific answer, challenge them on any ways that involve human interpretation of context, such as knowing that a name is most likely text and an age is most likely a number.  Assure them that they will look at the problem again in a couple of lessons.

[][0]

-   [Keeping Data Secret][1] - Exemplar ([PDF][2] \| [DOCX][3])

[/][0]

dsls.teacher_markdown:
The message itself is a doughnut, thumbs down, and angry face.  Students may have fun coming up with their own interpretations of the emojis.  One possible interpretation is that the sender expected a doughnut, didn't get one and became angry, but there is no "right" answer to what the emojis mean.

### What information do you need to help you decode it?

# Student record
0
1
2
3
## The student record holds information according to the following rules: *

The first eight bits store the student's grade as a binary number.

*

The second eight store the student's age as a binary number.

*

The next eight store the student's first initial in ASCII.

*

The last eight store the student's last initial in ASCII.
dsls.teacher_markdown:
[key]

**Byte 0:** The student is in Grade 9.

**Byte 1:** The student is 15 years old.

**Byte 2** The student's first initial is "J".

**Byte 3** The second initial is "H".

[/key]

https://studio.code.org/s/csd5-2019/less.long_instructions:
# Pizza Party

The pizza party data has been put into an app for you, and the answers from another class have been added.  Because this is an app, we can automate the creation of the bar chart from the given data.

# Do This

-   Click "Run" to see the list of answers that the classes have given.
-   Discuss with a partner what you think the chart of this data will look like.
-   Click "Show Chart" to see for yourself.

# Spreadsheet Version

The pizza party data has also been put into a spreadsheet for you, if you would like to use it instead.  To use the spreadsheet, you'll need to make your own copy of it.

-   This link will make you your own copy of the "Pizza Topping Choices" data: [Pizza Topping Choices][0]
-   You can also download a CSV version of the file [here][1].

# Pizza Party

When people work with data, they know to leave off answers that don't make sense, and that some answers, such as "peppers", "pepppers" and "green peppers", actually meant the same thing. Computers don't know how to do this, so we have to clean the data before the computer is able to use it.

This version of the app has a second column for data to be cleaned.

## Do this

-   Click "Run" to see the new list of answers to be cleaned.
-   Click on each answer that needs to be cleaned and correct it so that the computer will chart it properly. (You may want to delete some answers entirely.)
-   When you are finished, click "Show Chart" to see the new chart of cleaned answers.

Cake FlavorIcing Flavor
1Chocolate CakeChocolate Icing

3Chocolate CakeChocolate Icing
4Carrot CakeCream Cheese Icing
5Carrot CakeVanilla Icing
6Chocolate CakeChocolate Icing
7Chocolate CakeCream Cheese Icing
8Carrot CakeCream Cheese Icing


If these people had to agree on one cake and icing combination for a party, what should it be? What if they were able to order two cakes with icing? How does knowing both choices help us better understand what sort of cakes we should order?

questions.text: I like computer science.
I have the ability to learn computer science.
I like this computer science class.
I feel comfortable in this computer science class.

answers.text: No, it is dishonest to change the data before putting it into a chart.
Yes, they should correct misspellings and standardize names so the chart is more accurate.
Yes, they should take out places that they think will not be good for the class trip.
No, changing data will confuse people when their answers aren't in the chart.
No, if the data has problems, they should give the survey again.

questions.text: A class took a survey to decide where to go on a class trip, and they want to make a chart to see how popular each choice was. Will the need to make any changes to the data before creating the chart?

answers.text: The system must only use two different elements to encode information.
Everyone who uses it must agree on the rules of the system.
The rules of the system must clear, so that there's only one way to interpret encoded information.
The system should have a pattern, so that it is easy to remember.
The key for the system should be kept secret so that people cannot spy on the information.

questions.text: Which of the following TWO things are necessary for any encoding system to work?

answers.text: Making sure that the algorithm used to encrypt the data is kept a secret
Making sure that the key used to encrypt the data is kept a secret
Staying aware of data you might be producing, even unintentionally
Keeping the devices that have data on them physically secure (locking doors, etc.)
Using a strong key that cannot be easily guessed

questions.text: When keeping data secure, which of the following is NOT a concern?

answers.text: It's impossible to tell from this information.

dsls.markdown: The following chart shows the relationship between favorite animals and favorite seasons.

questions.text: What is the most popular of the animals, according to this chart?

answers.text: It's impossible to tell from this information.

questions.text: If someone told you their favorite season was autumn, what animal are they most likely to prefer, according to this chart?

dsls.markdown:
# CS Discoveries Post-Course Survey

**Your input and feedback is important to us!** We use it to:

* understand your experience
* make improvements to the course

Thanks for taking the time to help make CS Discoveries even better!

dsls.title: CS Discoveries End of Semester Student Survey

dsls.markdown:
### **This survey is anonymous** 

*Code.org takes your privacy very seriously.* Your responses here will be kept **anonymous**. No one, not even your teacher, can link your responses back to you as an individual.

We do this because we want you to **be as open and honest as possible**. We care about your experience in the course, and we make improvements based on what you say.

* The survey should take **10 minutes or less** to complete.

***

## School in general

#### *First, we want to ask you about your thoughts and feelings about school, in general.*
dsls.teacher_markdown:
## How to see your students' responses to this survey

* You will be able to see the anonymized results of the survey for your students once at least 5 of them have completed it.

* To view the results of this survey please follow the intstructions in the associated lesson plan.

questions.text: I think my schoolwork is interesting.
It is important for me to be good at my schoolwork.
I can really be myself at school.

dsls.markdown:
### Part 2: Computer Science in general

#### *Next, we'd like to ask for your thoughts and feelings about Computer Science, generally.*

***

questions.text: I like computer science.
I think computer science is interesting.
It is important to me to be good at computer science.
I have the ability to learn computer science.
I am better at computer science than other kids at my school.
People like me do computer science.
I think I could become a computer scientist one day.
I believe some people are just naturally better at learning and doing computer science than others.
Every person has the same ability to learn computer science, no matter what their gender, skin color, or background.
Each person has the same ability to learn and do computer science.

dsls.markdown:
### Part 3: You and computer science

#### *Next we ask for your thoughts about this computer science class and your future.* 

***

questions.text: I like this computer science class.
I feel comfortable in this class.
Sometimes I feel unsure whether I belong in this class.
I can really be myself in this computer science class.
I sometimes worry that I am seen by others as less capable in computer science.

answers.text: Wanted to, just couldn't due to scheduling conflicts or other constraints (few elective slots, class full, etc.)
Thought it would be too hard or they'd get a bad grade
Thought it would be boring, wouldn't learn anything useful
Had a bad experience in another computer science class
Worried they would feel like an outsider, few friends in the class
No parent or relative encouraged them
No one at the school (teacher, counselor, coach, etc.) encouraged them
Someone actively encouraged them NOT to take the class

questions.text: Think of a friend of yours at school who didn't take this class, but you think might have enjoyed it. What do you think are the strongest reasons why they didn't take this class? (choose up to two).

dsls.markdown:
## Your Classroom Experience ***

Take a moment to think back over the experiences you had in this class.
Thinking back over your time in this class, how often did your teacher do the following?

answers.text: Once or more per class session

questions.text: Asked me to consider relationships between what I was learning in the lesson and real world problems (meaning actual events or situations within or outside of school).

answers.text: Once or more per class session

questions.text: Connected a lesson or classroom activities to my own life (for example: by asking about my past experiences, or applying content to my daily life).

answers.text: Once or more per class session

questions.text: Asked me to problem solve when something didn't work the way I wanted it to work.

answers.text: Once or more per class session

questions.text: Asked me to explain the logic and reasoning supporting my solutions to problems.

answers.text: Once or more per class session

questions.text: Worked collaboratively with other students in a small group.

answers.text: Once or more per class session

questions.text: Shared responsibility for activity and project work with group members.

answers.text: Once or more per class session

questions.text: Made my own choices about assignments in computer science class.
How did you like the lessons and topics covered in this course?

dsls.markdown:
<!--
right 'nothing'  
right 'too little'
right 'about the right amount'
right 'too much'
right 'way too much'-->

questions.text: How challenging were the lessons and topics in this course for you? I think this course was...
I would recommend this computer science class to another student.
Asked me to write code with another student (Pair Programming)
Asked my peers to give me feedback on my work.
Asked me to share my ideas with classmates in small-group or large-group discussion.
Reminded me that failure is natural and expected part of a problem solving process.
Gave me the opportunity to write my thoughts down in a journal, or on paper.
Tried new things in class even when I was not sure how to do them.
Tried something I thought I might fail.
Stopped to consider alternative approaches to what I was working on.
Explain why I agreed or disagreed with the work of other students.
